This is almost certainly a mushroom that contains Psilocybine. Leaning towards something from the genus Gymnopilus, but not entirely sure.

These are Trichocereus taquimbalensis. Trichocereus terscheckii has different spines. Trichocereus werdermannianus has similar spines, but only because it's heavily influenced by Trichocereus taquimbalensis as well.

Sounds like a great mix for sowing out, but I wouldn't use it for larger plants. Pumice and Lava are perfect for cactus soil and I use them as main ingredients in my soil. They work so good you could use them without adding in anything else. Personally, I do mix a bit of Coir into the mix to improve the soil's ability to store water and make it more compact, but I wouldn't use more than 10-15%. There are cacti who don't mind having wet feet, but the more Coir you put in the longer it takes for it to dry. That said, I've seen people having great results with Coir as main medium, if the climate supports it. It's much safer to use minerals like Pumice though.
Check out the spines on this Trichocereus taquimbalensis. It's exactly the same spination. https://trichocereus.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Trichocereus-Taquimbalensis-807.jpg
Compared to this, here's the spines on one of the many forms of Trichocereus terscheckii. http://trichocereus.net/wp-content/uploads/Trichocereus_terscheckii_pm.jpg

I've only seen the first three or four. These show Trichocereus taquimbalensis. Now that I've seen the full album on imgur I've also seen a Trichocereus terscheckii. So you indeed have two different species there.

These are normally pollinated by bats and moths, so it's important that they are only open when the pollinators are active. Some only stay open a few hours. It's a desirable trait when they stay open for various days.

WRITING.TEXT: Growing cacti is one of the most rewarding things I ever did. It changed my life in countless ways, and only for the better. You know, you don't really make a lot of money from it, but the fact that I can finally live my dream and create my own cactus hybrids is very well worth it. Took me lots of time and work to have a setup that works with my climate and I'm very happy I stuck with it through the difficult times. Every new flower that opens is a new surprise, because you never know how they look. #128522;

Yeah, it's awesome and now is the best time for it. Just having something like 200 new flowers opening up at the moment, and I have to select the best ones for propagation. Today I had 10-15 and almost all of them looked great. Very rewarding job and it was always my dream. Worked hard for years to get a new greenhouse and this is the first season after I finally got one. #9786;

WRITING.TEXT: Yeah, wouldn't worry about it. That said, the colder the winter temperatures the less likely it is that you run into trouble with etiolation. Best temperature is around 10 #8304; Celsius and at that temperature the plants hibernate through winter. The warmer it is, the more sun and nutrients you need to prevenr etiolation.

Hey mate, Trichocereus cuzcoensis is described as having swollen spine bases and Trichocereus peruvianus does not have them. Trichocereus cuzcoensis has a higher rib count and Trichocereus cuzcoensis grows in the Cusco area. So it's limited in regards to its distribution.

Hard to tell when the main stem is missing. It's either a Trichocereus knuthianus or a Trichocereus peruvianus. With these spines, Trichocereus bridgesii can be ruled out.

Lots of species or even genera can cross with each other and it's not a reliable tool to judge about genetic proximity. It can help as an indicator because some wildly different cacti do not match and usually do not cross, but there's an endless list of cacti that do cross, eventhough they are rather distant. Wide crosses like these can have a higher risk of infertile or genetically weak offspring, but ot normally isn't a problem within the genus Trichocereus.

WRITING.TEXT: I'm a cactus breeder and I spent a few thousand on two high quality greenhouses. I've always dreamed about breeding cacti commercially, but was never able to afford it. Ten years ago I was really poor and could barely cover the heating costs for my own house, not speaking of heating or buying greenhouses. But yeah, worked very hard and was finally able to afford these two greenhouses recently. They are very well built with massive Aluminum that withstands strong storms, and the window glass is super thick polycarbonate with UV coating to prevent sunburn. Before I bought these, I had a super cheap China greenhouse that was so shaky that I spent whole nights in the garden trying to keep it together, and when it finally went airborne one day I finally decided to never buy cheap again. Best decision I've made in a long time. In the past, I woke up at every little wind because I was worried it would get damaged again. Now I sleep like a baby, even when there's heavy storm. I know both are very well built and nothing will happen. And the cacti love them. Feeling blessed and I'd always buy these again.
"The Mobile Infantry made me the man I am today!"

WRITING.TEXT: I live in Germany and both of the number plates shown on these two cars aren't normal German plates. They almost always have two letters at the front (some combinations cannot be used because of the strict anti-nazi laws) and KKK isn't possible like that either. There are other number plates for diplomats, Bundeswehr, Police, Insurance companies etc, but none would be crazy enough to get KKK as they are a banned organization here. It's definitely possible that the photo was taken in Germany and shows a car from another country, but you'd probably get in real trouble if you'd try to officially ask for that plate in Germany. And yeah, German number plates are bigger, so not sure where it's from. Could be Austria, Poland, etc. Can't see it well enough.

Alright, thanks for clearing it up. Crazy to see that people drive around like this. Over here, they'd be stopped by Police all the time. And yeah, they'd probably instantly land on a list of watched people. Lol.

In these areas, Asbestos is an important factor that can make a big difference when taking down the wrong trap house. Asbestos has to be removed in a wet state to prevent the particles from going airborne and the houses there have a lot of it. So if house A is listed as containing no Asbestos and they bring Mr. MC Hammer to tear down the whole thing and knock down the wrong house using no such protection instead, they can cover the whole area including neighboring houses with particles. Needless to say, it can potentially cause immense liability issues in case someone can prove they didn't follow suit there and I think that's one of the main reasons it could be a problem.
Strongly leaning towards a dried Psilocybe mushroom as well. They stain blue.

Putting in a few cheap jump scares is much easier to do than crafting genuinely scary and creepy horror. It's a cheap trick that lots of mediocre directors can pull off. It's become so predictable that you can even hear them coming in because they normally reduce the volume before them to increase the effect. I think it's poor film making and it makes me appreciate horror films that don't resort to it even more.

The part at the top with the pins is probably what's left of a wood handle. This is how rotten iron knifes or tools with wood handle look after they've been in the ground for a long time. The wood usually rots away and you end up with the pins and the rusty metal. Hard to tell what it exactly was, but it could've very well been a knife. There isn't enough substance left to say for sure.

The material is Bronze and it looks old enough to be Roman. Very hard to guess what it originally was though. Could've been a knob or a handle, something decorative, an animal statue etc. It kind of looks like a horse-head with the mouth at the long center part and the two ears at the top. This would point towards a knob from a knife or weapon. But yeah, probably Roman or very early medieval at the latest. Nice!

WRITING.TEXT: It strikes me as a Roman hairpin, made of Bronze. Check out the examples on the lower left. https://i.pinimg.com/564x/45/8d/62/458d62ba1ce403772001e1d8ee82430d.jpg

Sure, as long as metal detecting is legal where you live it would probably not hurt to show it to an archaeologist. #128521;Most are very nice and happy to help identifying something like this. The material is definitely Bronze. It is a bit thicker than most other hairpins we see around Europe, but I still think it's probably one. The circle at the top could've held something like a decorative stone. I love pins because they often have a wonderful patina.

WRITING.TEXT: I see the similarities to WW2 German medals, but I am pretty sure it's not German. At least not from the German military. To me it looks like it could be a somewhat primitive cast or small scale private production. Original medals from this time were very detailed and even the late WW2 stuff has a different quality than this one. It looks interesting and I have no idea about Finnish medals, but a few more photos from all angles including the back wouldn't hurt. Medals usually have tiny makers marks.

WRITING.TEXT: Yeah, this belongs to Echinopsis terscheckii, also known as Trichocereus terscheckii. When and how to water it depends on your climate. If this is an inside plant, I'd probably put it in mineral soil consisting of mostly Pumice, Lava and a bit of sowing soil or coir mixed in between. Then they are more forgiving than when you have em in a rather organic soil. My plants are in a greenhouse and I only water them between March and October. During winter the temperatures are very low and the plants kinda hibernate. When kept inside, you'd best overwinter it at 10 degree Celsius and with barely any water until spring. If you keep it at room temperatures with heating, you need to water it every once in a while and provide enough light to keep it from etiolating. But don't overdo it with the water and let the soil dry out in between watering. Soil that stays wet for too long is a lot more problematic than watering a bit late. These cacti are relatively drought tolerant, but the roots can rot very easily.

WRITING.TITLE: One of the Hildewintera hybrids I have for crosses with Trichocereus.

WRITING.TEXT: Alright, what I can tell you that the material is cast iron. So it might have been made to resemble an original medal. Time frame is almost certainly after WW2 and looks like a very rough work. Stuff like this was sometimes made for veteran meetups or something unofficial like medals made at the frontlines. It doesn't have a lot of wesr though. Could even be something like carnival medals or a later reproduction made to resemble the German medals from WW2. I can definitely rule out anything official from the German military for this one. There are some late German medals that have wonky quality due to shortage of metals and where the eagle resembles a chicken a little bit, but nothing like this. I don't think it would've passed quality control of any of the medal makers at the time. And yeah, since it also seems to lack a maker's mark, I think this is something unofficial. Sorry, wish I could help more than that.

It kind of reminds me of an older grease gun for putting grease on window seals and stuff like that. Once found one and it took forever to identify it. http://img.auctiva.com/imgdata/4/6/8/8/3/1/webimg/413925560_tp.jpg

WRITING.TEXT: Yes, these Echinopsis species often work as fathers for Trichocereus species. However, using Scop and similar Trichocereus species as father for these Echinopsis almost always fails. This is due to the long tubes on the Echinopsis flowers. The Trichocereus pollen is just hot made to reach the ovum at the bottom of the Echinopsis flower tube.

And yeah, haven't been happier ever since. You normally take pollen from one Cactus and put it on the stigma of another flower. This way you get seeds. It's extremely rewarding when you see your own hybrids growing up.
Thank you, greatly appreciated. #128522;
Yeah, this one really blew me away. I get quite a lot that have more than one flowers, but this one here was special. Look really great!

It really depends on your climate and the cacti you choose. Some like Echinopsis, Epiphyllum, Cleistocactus Chamaecereus (now seen as Lobivia) and Mammillaria flower very easily and reliably, even if you can only bring them outside in summer. So if you want to start with something, these were the most reliable in regards to flowering. Some others require a dark and cold winter period to flower reliably, for example Trichocereus. I had lots of trouble getting my larger Trichocereus to flower until I got a greenhouse. It's just closer to their natural environment and the greenhouse is one of the reasons my plants flower a lot now. I also fertilize regularly and give my plants all kinds of plant extracts to spoil them. Lol. It's not really low maintenance, but it's very fun as soon as you finally get to the point where they thrive.

WRITING.TEXT: Here's an old photo that shows the cheap discount greenhouse I got after the first real storm. Got it ages ago but had a bad feeling after seeing the manual, so I had put the actual completion on hold for some years. But eventually I got my ass up to put it together and the building process was already a nightmare. Sarah's parents helped with the construction and I wanna just say that it put the whole family under substantial stress. #128513; After weeks of dealing with the crappy system, we got it up though. For a while. So, we had storm and I already spent the night outside trying to keep the light and cheap window panels from flying away. Injured myself pretty badly on the sharp frame and ended up putting in additional hooks on the base and glued some of the panels into the frame. Then I went to bed, tired, exhausted and depressed because I realized I was a fool to spend so little on something this important for a breeder. Right after going pro, I wanted to get everything done right away. No patience, just passion. Let's say mistakes were made. So yeah, came out the morning after and couldn't see the greenhouse on the place it was built. I was like "nah, that can't be" because I had basically cemented the whole frame into the ground like an Egyptian pyramid. So I went to check and found the train wreck you can see on the pic. The base was still there, but the cheap hook system that held the greenhouse on the base had failed. The greenhouse hit a tree stump and looked like the torn apart garbage can it actually was. Took me days to collect all the trash from my garden and all the plants that were inside were pretty much lost. That day I went inside and went straight to bed. Like, at 10 in the morning. #128514; When I got up, I got me a pickaxe and and axe and punched the living hell out of the greenhouse's corpse, and with it burying my dreams for another year. That's the end of my tale about Patrick and the garbage greenhouse. In 2017 I decided to buy me a quality greenhouse from a German manufacturer and I completely love it. Its frame and base are solid Aluminum that has an included warranty of 15 years or so, and super thick lexan windows that filter UV. The system is so well built that it would probably withstand any kind of storm that we get here. Earlier I spent whole nights in the garden looking for my trash. Now I sleep like a baby, even at the worst storms. Money well spent. #129392;

WRITING.TEXT: You know, it really depends how much water reserves they still have. I generally avoid watering seedlings in organic soil too early in the season, and if I do it it's only when it's really necessary. A bit of water now might not hurt and even improve their health a bit short term, but with late frosts still coming it would probably be a bit of a gamble how fast the soil gets dry again and how cold it actually gets. Really depends on the temperatures and air humidity in the coming weeks. If you decide to spray them a bit, be rather conservative with the water and don't water again until it's dry.

WRITING.TEXT: I haven't heard anyone with real experience saying that. #128513; Generally speaking, V-notches are a lot less common on PC, but they are well documented. And yeah, stuff like this is really of limited value because all kinds of clones, hybrids and PC offspring are often identified as PC. Usually via poor photos and without actual knowledge of the fact that one and the same clone can look wildly different, depending on where it is grown. How would someone know if a plant is the actual cloned PC, or PC offspring which just follows the phenotype of the mother/father? So yeah, I'd take everything written about PC with a grain of salt.

WRITING.TEXT: I'm pretty sure I know where they came from. This should be a strain from the Chavin Herbalist Matucana collection. The area is full of Trichocereus peruvianus, with very very few Trichocereus pachanoi in between. They did collect seeds from some Trichocereus pachanoi in private gardens, but it's pretty likely they were open pollinated with nothing but Trichocereus peruvianus growing around them. So it would make sense that the offspring goes towards Trichocereus peruvianus. But yeah, could also be that they had trouble telling the difference between a rather spineless Peru and a Trichocereus pachanoi. #129335; #8205; #9794; #65039;

WRITING.TITLE: First Trichocereus Flowers of the Season

WRITING.TEXT: Ha ha, I know very well how that feels. #128513;
Potted this plant in a mix of pure Pumice and Lava and it responded greatly. It has pupped right away at the base, and both main columns are actively growing beautifully. Lovely plant!

This is a sunburn because the pup was in total darkness underground. Some heal, some do not. Since it's at the base it could theoretically spread to the main column IF it doesn't heal and spread. Big IF. I'd probably remove all soil around the pup to keep it ventilated and visible. If necessary you can cut the pup at the bottom of the pup. Try not to cut the main column, just the pup.

You have lots of time as long oxygen is getting all around the pup. Infections rarely spread to or from pups and if they do it often takes months. I had one just like this one and I just cut away the upper half of the pup and the bottom has now pupped again. But yeah, you can observe this for a few weeks to see how it goes. My gut feeling is that it might very well heal, but it will always look a bit messy and pose a risk of it coming back after a longer time. Happens rarely too, but does happen every now and then.

Happy to help. If the infection goes deeper than what's visible it's best to cut it off now. It looks like it might've spread to the core and if that's the case you would probably see more damage further down. If it's in the core the pup is lost. Stuff like this is often unpredictable because you can't see what's inside. If in doubt, wait a bit and cut it off if it gets worse.

It's not that Neem oil cannot be used. It is great when it works, but you have to be extremely careful about sunburn because the plants become super sensitive during and after treatment. Alternatives for oily products are pesticides that only have the active Neem chemical (I think Azamax is one), Spinosad, Imidacloprid, Neonicotinoids. Needless to say some are very toxic and might even not be permitted in your country. Some of these pests are very hardy and it's not easy to kill them. So there isn't an easy formula you can follow.

WRITING.TITLE: Had to share my crazily photogenic Cactus flower!

WRITING.TEXT: This is the American Trichocereus hybrid First Light by Mark Dimmit. On the photo the flower isn't fully open yet and it even looks better when it's fully open. Totally love it.

Hey mate, strongly leaning towards Trichocereus peruvianus, similar to Matucana and Icaro DNA. It looks like it didn't really produce very strong spines, so it looks a bit untypical. More sun and more fertilizer and this plant will turn out amazingly. #129392;

Yeah, the difference in skin color is probably because of it being kept out of the sun a bit. The spines are a bit smaller like they'd normally be too. And yeah, every plant has a different nutrient availability due to soil pH, soil composition and other chemicals present in the soil, genetic situation or infections, brand of fertilizer used etc. It also depends on how they were grown before you got them.
Hey mate, even better! It looks amazing now! #128522;
Yeah, lovely photo! #128513;
It's a Trichocereus cuzcoensis. The spine growth in center is often more helpful determining if something has swollen spine bases or not.
What was it sold as? Like, did the seller add any locality or strain info? The whole seed and plant market from Peru is a mess, so this happens a lot.

Spines in the middle part of the plant. Species with swollen spine bases (which T.cuzcoensis belongs to) can grow spines without swollen spine base at the new growth, but the older spines at the bottom very often do show the typical swollen spine bases.

KK242 was sold as a Trichocereus peruvianus. It came from the Peruvian collector Karel Knize and he sold like 10 different strains under that name. Every one of them different, some were Trichocereus peruvianus, but most came out classic Trichocereus cuzcoensis like what you have there. Knize's numbers stand for a certain area, e.g. KK242 from Matucana. This means all plants he collected in Matucana were sold as KK242. It's not how most field botanists label their collections and I can't recommend that system because of all the problems it creates. Here's an article on the subject. https://trichocereus.net/kk242-trichocereus-cuzcoensis-more/
Looks kinda similar to Torres amp; Torres. Very spiny. #128077;

Trichocereus werdermanianus, gotta repot this one this year. Was concerned about the roots and put it in a soil with great drainage, but now it's time for a Pumice heavy soil. Gotta do a lot of repotting this year. Large plants too. Pretty sure my fingers will be in a world of pain. #128513;

Yeah, but that one isn't even the worst. Trichocereus strigosus is one of my personal nightmares. They have spines everywhere and always fall over when you repot them. As I type this I have messed up fingers from spines on both hands. Lol. Should've become a Bonsai breeder instead. #128514;

WRITING.TITLE: When you suddenly realize you have WAY too many plants. Also known as Cactus PTSD.

WRITING.TEXT: Yes, but only on plants I don't care too much about. It can have lots of side effects, even if applied correctly and out of the sun.

Generally speaking, I can recommend Spinosad, Spruzit, Azamax or Imidacloprid. Not all of those might be permitted where you live. Neem oil and white oil can also be used for treatment of the soil/roots alone, but I personally wouldn't use them on precious plants and avoid doing it in the sun and not on the body itself. There's people that use Neem on their plants without running into problems as long as they keep their plants in the dark for weeks, but I'm not a fan of oil. But yeah, these are the most effective ones that are still available in some countries. Hope it helps.

Echinopsis subdenudata is one of the oldest plants that were used in hybrid breeding. There are some very beautiful hybrids involving it, and most follow Echinopsis subdenudata in regards to the rib shape. The flowers of Echinopsis subdenudata are white in color, but there #180;s still a lot of unused potential because of their beautiful shape. I #180;ve seen very nice hybrids between Trichocereus scopulicola and E.subdenudata and I am sure there will be many more hybrids involving it in the future. If your goal is to breed hybrids with a beautiful and unique body, Echinopsis subdenudata should be on top of your list! https://youtube.com/watch?v=BTDZoMTsxd8
Hey mate, nice find! #128077;I'd definitely take that one home.

Flower buds everywhere! #129392; It's really great to see that all the little things I've been doing since last year paid off. #128077;Starting from picking the optimal winter temperatures, the ideal light/sun intensity, the different fertilizers and my special herbal extracts to improve the general health and flowering and and and. It's a lot of work, and I'm just glad my plants respond so well to it. It's been a LONG way with lots of setbacks and losses getting to this point, and there's still so many things to learn or improve. I know it can be hard when you are a beginner and lose plants left and right, but I can assure everyone that it's SO worth it in the end. Ignore the setbacks and keep improving, and it will be one of the most rewarding hobbies you can think of. #129392; #9996; #129392;

WRITING.TITLE: Part of My Collection (and something personal in the comments)

WRITING.TEXT: Part of my collection. The video was taken roughly a week ago and since then the plants have gotten lots and lots of flower buds. Almost all of the mature plants I own are flowering and I'm just extremely proud about having reached this stage as a breeder. There were times when it was a pain and frustration, times when I lost plant after plant. I think in my whole career as a breeder I had at least two moments when I thought I couldn't take it anymore and wanted to stop breeding cacti completely. Luckily I stuck to it and every setback brought me a bit closer to my goal of becoming a world class Cactus breeder. When my plants didn't flower, I researched and worked on my methods until they did. When they wouldn't grow or had root rot, I adapted and changed the soil they got and looked into the whole field of fertilizers and plant extracts that are out there. And with every little new thing I learned, I became a better breeder. All of this has also made me a better person and I have never been more happy and proud my whole life. Long story short, NEVER STOP LEARNING. Every little piece brings you closer to the whole picture, like a puzzle. #9996; #128077;

Hell to the Yeah! So many flower buds it's getting difficult to pollinate them all. This is just one, and most of my plants look like this too. My special flower formula and the fertilizers are working wonders. #129395; #128077;
Yeah, that's the plan. #128522; Hope some of the crosses will take. If only a tenth of the flowers take it'll be an awesome breeding year. #128077;

WRITING.TITLE: I celebrate every new Pup on my Plants.

WRITING.TEXT: Hey mate, the main focus on these books are hybrids involving species like Trichocereus pachanoi, Trichocereus peruvianus, Trichocereus scopulicola, etc. It's crowdfunded so we didn't have enough pages to bring in many other hybrids like the Arizona hybrids, but I will almost certainly make a book just for those one day. Not sure if we can finance the printing, but we'll definitely try and it that shouldn't work out we'll bring it as an eBook. #128077;

Hey mate, DHL is pissing me off. Lol. I'm calling them like once a week and they have no clue about how long it'll take. I don't expect it to last longer than 2-3 months. They did the same with China and they already ship there again now. Keeping my fingers crossed because I want to get back to shipping to my Australian brothers again. #128522;

Fertilization Day. Holy moly, this is serious work. Now is the time that matters the most, so I provide lots of water and nutrients. Since I started watering and fertilizing angrily, lots of plants that are actually not big enough to flower yet have pushed out flower buds. And yeah, the majority of the plants already have lots of flower buds and it's only the very beginning of the season. There will be more flushes. It's actually some kind of art and once you get to the point where you can see your plants react well to your treatment, you feel like the king of the world. #128522;

Yes, get a top notch commercial grade fertilizer for sensitive and expensive crops that doesn't cause burns. If I'd do the fertilizing regimen that I'm doing with some of the cheaper fertilizers I'd burn the hell out of my plants. Also, it shouldn't be too high in N because it causes follow up problems like vulnerability to fungal infections if there's too much N in the fertilizer. Right now I use Wuxal Super as regular fertilizer and Hakaphos Soft Novelle as flower fertilizer. Wuxal is something like 8-8-11 and Hakaphos is 11-11-30. You probably won't get those brands outside the EU, but there are almost certainly comparable ones where you live. Wuxal has a pH buffer that sets the pH at 5.5 to 6.5 and can be foliar fed and the plants love it. And yeah, good mineral soil is essential. I mostly use Pumice, Lava and Coir. Maybe a bit of charcoal but that's it. The mineral soil dries out faster, which allows you to fertilize and water more during the import time between March and September. I water and fertilize at least once a week during the main season and I spray with plant extracts like garlic, Valerian flower, horsetail, coconut water etc once a week too. Lots of work, but the plants love it and I have so many flowers I have trouble pollinating them all. #128522; #128077; Came a long way to this point and if I can do it everyone can. You learn from every failure and loss you have and I had many. Lol.

Had a stormy night and the wind knocked this one over. No real damage on the plant though, and it fell the best possible way it could've fallen. Everything else would've probably knocked down some flower buds. #128077;
I'm pretty sure one of the parents had some connection to the whole Trichocereus cuzcoensis complex too. Any info on the cross or seller?

Hey mate, great to see you around. #128522; I personally use smaller pots to promote flowering and my results prove me right. I do not want my plants to invest all their energy into growing a bigger rootstock. I'm a breeder and to me it's most important they flower. Smaller pots dry out faster, which means I can water and fertilize more often, without keeping the roots wet for weeks. So yeah, they flower a lot more like this because of how I fertilize and water in between drying out. During the flower season they get water and fertilizer twice a week. It's a special fertilizer for expensive and sensitive crops called Wuxal Super and it's 8-8-11. It has a pH buffer and foliar feeding. I also use a flower fertilizer called Hakaphos Soft Novelle that's something like 11-11-30.

Tough shit! This slug tried taking a bite of one of my favorite hybrids, but the Cactus defended itself very efficiently. #128077; #128077; #128077; I generally do not kill slugs or snails, but when they off themselves like this I'm not really crying either. There are so many vegetables that don't have a million lethal spines in em around the greenhouse, so this was quite unnecessary. #129300; #127797;

That's a reliable seller. #128077; Last year I bought me a 20 Liter can of Wuxal for something like 80 Euro and it will probably last me until the end of time. Lol. Can't really recommend buying such big cans though, since it's a pain to handle them. Tore me a muscle lifting it and even after a year it still hurts sometimes. Lol.

In this video I show one of my soil mixes and show how i repot a larger number of plants that I got from a fellow breeder. I normally use a mix between Pumice, Lava and other ingredients and I talk more about it in this video. I use all kinds of soil mixes, and this is just one of them, but looking back it produced some amazing results and I will probably pick a similar one again this year. Hey mate, sunburn isn't really an issue to me since I keep my plants outside in the greenhouses all year round. Sunburn happens a lot when people are overwintering their plants inside and bring them out in spring. That aside, last year was the hottest summer ever recorded with the most brutal UV we ever had. There were some plants that had minor spots here and there during the height of the record heatwave, and this year might even be worse. We'll see. But sunburn can be an issue, but in good quality greenhouses it's often not.
Hey mate, nothing is really known about this clone. Probably not a hybrid though. Bought as botanical Trichocereus pachanoi.

WRITING.TITLE: I Love Being a Cactus Breeder!

WRITING.TEXT: Hey mate, a great quality fertilizer and a good soil are what helped me the most. Also, a cold winter period helps a lot to induce flowering. And yeah, lots of little things like plant extracts to help with general health (Valerian flower extract, coconut water, horsetail extract, garlic, seaweed etc.) It's certainly a lot of work, but if you want to get as many flowers as possible these things all add up. If you need help or advice I'm always happy to help. #128522;

Been there, done that. #128513; Killed so many plants that I sometimes cringe at night, but at some point you run out of mistakes to make. Next time water some more, or get a soil that holds water a bit longer. Pumice is a great mineral with amazing capabilities to store water. It's my main medium these days.
Ha ha, yeah, my grandma has a Cactus with a plastic flower and I haven't had the heart to tell her it's fake yet. She's so proud of her good Cactus care. Lol.

WRITING.TEXT: Yes, definitely one of the most gracile ones. I personally love the populations from Isla Del Sol the most. #129392;

Here's what I do to bulk plants up. Every plant that I get gets fatter and most end up with twice the diameter they had before. I use Wuxal Super as main fertilizer and Hakaphos Soft Novelle as flower fertilizer. In addition I give Valerian flower extract, Horsetail extract, seaweed extract, garlic extract, coconut water and a corn extract with a sour pH buffer. You don't need all of those and you can replace the fertilizer brands with stuff you have available in your country, but if you use something like this every 1-2 weeks your plants will go completely bonkers. #128526;

WRITING.TEXT: Extremely dehydrated. I'd repot these in a more mineral soil mix, regardless what they are in right now. And then, more water and fertilizer. This is pretty close to the point where they can't recover anymore.

Every plant has a different root system and nutrient availability. You can check the roots for problems like root Mealies and whether or not it even has an adequate root system. If it doesn't that might be the reason. Just because three plants are beside each other, it doesn't mean that all have the same root system. Another reason can be Virus infections, which can substantially weaken a plant and are hard to verify. Also, it's possible that the structure of the soil below this plant just doesn't store enough water compared to what's left and right of it. Theres many possibilities, so you really need to look into this more closely to find out why this one doesn't have adequate water and nutrient supply. The only thing that's obvious is that the water doesn't seem to get to the plant.

Hey mate, this is nothing I'd be concerned about. These are scars from an injury, and it will take many years until this is grown out. It's even possible it'll never grow out completely and it'll always have a bunch of scars around the base. It's not really an infection that keeps on going though. Scars change and might even look worse throughout the course of the healing, but there isn't anything you can do right now, apart from providing fresh air, good care and avoiding more injuries or sunburns.

It has turned into a serious task. Normally I'd just hose them all down twice a week and I'd be done in half an hour. However, I try to fertilize every time I'm watering during the main season and I can't do that with the hose. I need the right concentration of the fertilizer and I usually do it with large 10L cans. It takes a few hours per greenhouse and there are three of them. FML. Lol. I'll probably have to find a way to combine the hose with the fertilizer next year. Watering a collection this size with a can is like walking a little marathon.

It's either a Rauhocereus or one of the badass looking Cleistocactus like C.fieldianus. Definitely not a Trichocereus. Some Haageocereus can look similar too, but strongly leaning towards Cleistocactus.

WRITING.TEXT: Hey mate, it's a super rewarding hobby. Every year you can create your own hybrids and you never know what'll come from your crosses. Great feeling. #9786; #65039;

A used greenhouse. Growing plants in a greenhouse is one of the most rewarding things ever. You can raise so many amazing plants in there and working in the garden is great for mental health. Probably saved my life. Caring for plants and making them thrives gives me purpose. Great stuff.

There's few countries where you can plant everything out and if I'd do this where I live my plants would die reliably every year. There's frost hardy plants, but many aren't and would not survive the winter. With the greenhouse you can prolong the season. You already have your plants actively growing at a time when there's still night frosts between late February and April and It also adds a few months to your growing season towards the winter. And yeah, a greenhouse enables you to control the climate completely, which can never be done outside. It protects your seedlings from the elements and animals, which greatly increases your yield.

WRITING.TEXT: I am well aware of the description of Trichocereus macrogonus and its traits. This is a historic plant from the early time Trichocereus macrogonus was first cooked up and it's important to keep those plants labeled as they were. It has zilch to do with this plant being actually considered to be a correct Trichocereus macrogonus. It's keeping old labels around so we can trace back their history and which plants were applied to that name at the time. Just because we recently started applying the name Trichocereus macrogonus to a certain type of glaucous Matucana Peruvianus, it doesn't mean it was always like that. In the past there were at least seven Trichocereus species that were sold or thrown into that name, and even plants from the genus Pilosocereus. Trichocereus taquimbalensis has brown spines too and it would fit the description too. Older cultivars or clones that have history shouldn't be relabeled every time the wind of nomenclature blows into a certain direction. The description of Trichocereus macrogonus was a mess, lacking a description of the flowers, the country of origin, a herbarium specimen and anything other than the fact it is supposed to have brown spines. Joel is using the name for a certain form of Trichocereus peruvianus with brown spines and a slightly different body type, but you could put those into Peruvianus as well. It's a very variable species. The name Trichocereus macrogonus just doesn't meet scientific standards, so discussing what is or isn't a true Macrogonus is guessing. I agree that this plant isn't really the type of plant that fits the description terribly well, but it's still part of this species' history.

Yeah, the name Trichocereus macrogonus is problematic because there's no firm baseline to compare to. At the same time, the species is integral for the genus Trichocereus. I'm almost certain it'll be used for dark blue Trichocereus with brown spines like the ones from Matucana, but it comes with lots of baggage. I personally love this plant and it looks a bit different to most of my Trichocereus bridgesii, but I still see this one as something connected to Trichocereus bridgesii. Not sure who originally sold those as Macro, but he was probably just applying the name because of the long spines and the glaucous epidermis. Which looks like it's from another planet. #128076;

WRITING.TITLE: Trichocereus pachanoi x Echinopsis obrepanda v.toralapana Hybrid SAARWELLEN
Seedlings from Spring now getting Maximum Sun, Water and Nutrients!

WRITING.TEXT: Opened up my second batch of seeds sown in early spring 2020. They are now racing against the clock and need to grow as much as possible before the winter. They will now get full sun, full nutrients and no more humidity than what's absolutely necessary. I also put holes into them to provide drainage now. I want the soil to dry ASAP so I can water and fertilize more often. Overall, very happy with those. Almost all are already big enough to make it through winter.

Hey mate, I'm using Coir in all my soil mixes and it completely replaced peat for me. Love the stuff. #128077; This year my whole operation exploded and these were grown under minimal care. I have thrice as many seedlings in the other greenhouse and they're twice as big because I had more time for fertilizing repotting and watering. Wanted to make sure the seedlings can stay healthy until the main flower Flush is over and now I have finally more time for fertilizing, watering and that kind of stuff. They are already big enough to survive the winter, but they will grow substantially in the next weeks.

Hey mate, I've sown out between December-February and the seedlings from that time are roughly 2-3x as big as those here because they were fertilized a lot sooner. Was hit by a big flower Flush and just had to take care of that one first. The seedlings in the photo were sown between February and May and didn't get any fertilizer yet. I wanted to hold back nutrients to reduce fungal problems in the first couple months. You could grow those to thrice the size in the same time if you fertilize accordingly and put them in full sun. You'll have to do a lot more misting and watering then though.
Thanks mate, totally love it too. #128513; #128077;
Hey mate, thinking Espostoa or Weberbauerocereus. Trichocereus is out the question.

WRITING.TEXT: Thanks mate. Have been raising lots and lots of plants from seeds and am mostly keeping the most impressive ones. That and the nutrients and fertilizers I'm giving them....I'm giving low Nitrogen, high P and K and that just brings out the skin color very nicely.

Yeah, I want to get more Subdenudata hybrids with colored flowers and it would be awesome to get a cool mix between these two. The flower of the mother looks great and we'll spread them around to get them into the community.

Leaning towards Trichocereus tarmaensis. They usually look like this at this age, but post it again when it's bigger to confirm. Seedgrown plants need many years until they look like mature plants look eventually.

WRITING.TITLE: Trichocereus Hybrid Volta Lake x Cantora Gelb

WRITING.TEXT: Yeah, that's nothing to worry about. Might also be the start of aerial roots. It happens a lot on Trichocereus bridgesii. The correct Echinopsis name is Echinopsis lageniformis btw. Echinopsis bridgesii was already taken by a little Bolivian Echinopsis.
Spines can and will regrow. The random spine growth is probably a newer set of spines that grew after the original ones were lost. Happens quite a lot in healthy plants.

It always depends on the temperature you have in your grow room. The higher the temperature, the more light you need. You can keep plants in total darkness at 10 #176; Celsius and they will not etiolate. Once you put them in a heated living room they need light, water and nutrients.

WRITING.TITLE: Trichocereus strigosus/strigonus. A very spiny and painful plant.
Hildewintera Hybrid ANDENKEN AN FRIEDRICH RITTER

WRITING.TEXT: Hildewintera Hybrid ANDENKEN AN FRIEDRICH RITTER. Some of the last flowers of the season. Pollinated with Validus, Pachanoi x Thelegonoides, Haageocereus x Matucana, Liskes Feuerzauber and Altena. #128077;
Hope so. Season is almost over and it's getting cold soon. If I get one or two fruits from those crosses I'm already happy. #128513; #128077;

Could be correct. Trichocereus purpureopilosus is a species that belongs to the Trichocereus candicans/Trichocereus candicans complex and this one here has spines that fall within the range of Trichocereus candicans. Post the flowers when they open. #128077;

Well yeah, you sometimes see it on young Trichocereus seedlings, but it's rather rare. It could also be an Azureocereus hertlingianus/Browningia hertlingiana and at this size it's neatly impossible to keep them apart. A few more centimeters are necessary to say it for sure.

At this size it's difficult to differentiate all forms. There's total chaos because so many Trichocereus taquimbalensis are being sold as Trichocereus werdermannianus and Trichocereus werdermannianus is often sold as Trichocereus terscheckii. Imo this is Trichocereus taquimbalensis. Trichocereus werdermannianus is very fat and most younger ones look much more like dark gray Trichocereus terscheckii, which is what they are almost always identified as.
